awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Developing Sustainable Technologies for Removing Contaminants from Water using Natural Zeolite
awd_abstract_narration:
World-wide, serious inorganic contaminants in drinking water are a growing concern, particularly those resulting from industrial operations, such as mine-impacted rivers and streams, because these may themselves be sources of drinking water. However, current methods for the removal of pollutants such as arsenic, fluoride, strontium, uranium, iron, manganese, hardness and other heavy metals from industrial effluents are both difficult and expensive. Furthermore, these systems are often not used because they involve high capital, operational, and maintenance costs that require toxic chemicals, and produce solid residuals that need specialized handling and disposal. This I-Corps project will explore the commercial feasibility of a sustainable, simple, low-cost technology for water treatment. It is based on the use of zeolite, a natural mineral that is abundant and low cost. Removal by adsorption onto natural zeolites is the most economically feasible technology alternative for treating contaminated water. It is also anticipated that the zeolites and contaminants can be separated after treatment allowing the re-use of the zeolites and marketing of the contaminants for other industrial uses. The proposed technology can be used in a number of settings and for a number of potential end-users, regardless of where treatment is needed. It can be implemented at a central location in large volumes and then distributed through pipelines or bottled. It can be used by individuals in small volumes at a point of use or point of entry. It can be used by industries that require treatment of controlled or uncontrolled discharges of wastes. It can be used by industries that provide water treatment solutions for rivers, streams, or ground water. Everyone is interested in affordable alternatives to providing water suitable for human use or consumption.

The goal of the project is to develop an innovative technology with significant commercial potential for removing heavy metals and other inorganic contaminants from water. To achieve this goal, during the life of the project, the I-Corps team will 1) scope and assess the potential for commercialization of the proposed technology; 2) articulate the value propositions; 3) compare the costs of existing systems versus the proposed technology; and 4) determine methods to incorporate and test proposed materials into new or existing manufactured filters/systems. The UTEP team will determine the commercialization potential by conducting 100 interviews and developing a business model canvas that includes building blocks such as key partnerships, channels, key activities, revenue streams, and cost structures. The team will test the proposed technology into selected manufactured filters/systems and test and determine the potential for regeneration of zeolite versus disposal. The project has the potential for both technical and non-technical contributions. The proposed technology will provide individual consumers, public utilities, and industry alike, with a simple and cost-effective way to treat water contaminated with inorganic materials. Studies have the potential to develop a cost-effective arsenic "litmus" test. Additionally, the protocol derived from this project will be reproducible at a minimal cost in developing countries by using regionally available materials, and can be set up with a social entrepreneurial business model. Finally, the project will provide a foundation to develop an integrated curriculum in Innovation and Entrepreneurship (I&E) in a minority Hispanic Serving Institution, such as UTEP, to increase the number of female and Hispanic innovators as well as underrepresented minorities in STEM.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this NSF I-Corp project was to identify commercial potential, challenges, and opportunities of a sustainable process for removing heavy metals and other inorganic contaminants from water. The proposed technology uses surface-modified zeolite, a naturally occurring mineral, as a cation exchanger and molecular sieve for the removal of contaminants from water. The project also unveiled one of the key challenges in developing a technology for the removal of a specific heavy metal, arsenic, to measure its concentration in real time, and to ensure that the removal technology complies with safe drinking water standards.  We found that this is an innovation needed in the market for removal or detection of arsenic and other heavy metals.

More than 199 customer discovery interviews with potential customers were performed. Potential customer segments identified included water utility companies, companies that market bottled water and point of use water filters, companies that need to treat their wastewater, NGOs in developing countries, individual consumers in developed countries, the oil and gas industry, and companies that provide water treatment solutions. With the most promising customers in mind, a thesis vetted by the I-Corps teaching team was developed that reads as follows: Water treatment engineers working for the oil, gas, mining, and potable water industries have a need for a product that removes specific heavy metals in waters that are difficult to treat. The average cost savings required by the engineers is 15%. One of the most significant outcomes of the program was that with the help of the industry mentor and the I-Corps mentors we were able to identify the one customer segment that would benefit the most from our technology: the public water utilities.  In addition to narrowing down this customer, through the customer interviews we also found that for this customer segment it was as just as important to find ways to measure the concentrations of arsenic in real-time for operational and compliance purposes.  A number of challenges in the commercialization path of our arsenic removal device were revealed, namely the intellectual property, patent, and regulatory issues related to compliance and certification for the adoption of the technology for treating drinking water could be delayed for more than five years.

This program benefitted not only the Entrepreneurship Lead but also nine students that worked in interdisciplinary teams with mentorship provided by mentors from the industry and the UTEP College of Business.  The EL developed a business canvas model that included potential key partners, relationships, channels, cost structure, and revenue streams. This experience helped the EL better understand the workflow within the water industry and its regulatory issues, developed interpersonal skills, and established a professional network within the industry.  The students participated in regional competitions (Paso del Norte Venture Competition and the Texas Rural Challenge) that required them to provide detailed business models. These competitions included business model reports, presentations, elevator speeches, and poster presentations that helped them develop their oral and written communications skills.   A distinctive element of this project is that all the students were involved in real-life experience and entrepreneurship and were engaged in their careers and their communities with a problem that concerns everybody, not just a particular group.  This project has also provided activities and strategies to develop an integrated curriculum in Innovation and Entrepreneurship (I&E), to train Engineering students at UTEP, a minority Hispanic Serving institution, contributing towards the College’s mission of increasing the number of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM.
